items.title: Sheila Fitzpatrick: Diary
items.excerpt: Idon’t​ think I ever dobbed anybody in – or if I did, I would have told myself I was doing something else. Dobbing is the preferred Australian word for denunciation or snitching to the bosses, and it is taken to be a shameful betrayal of one’s fellow subalterns. I’m quite sure…

items.title: Emily Berry: I am entirely made of wood

items.title: Abigail Green: In Full Sail
items.excerpt: There are​ few pictures of rich Jews as enchanting as Renoir’s 1881 portrait of the young Cahen d’Anvers sisters, Elisabeth and Alice, with their chubby cheeks, pearly teeth, sturdy legs and frilly dresses. Or take Ingres’s earlier but equally celebrated portrayal of the Baron…

items.title: Unfit
items.excerpt: We don’t decide anything over the course of a lifetime, we follow our own lives meekly along signposted paths, half-heartedly trying to catch up, teetering on the edge of the abyss, asking the wrong person for help, hitchhiking along a dangerous highway, fleeing when it would’…

items.title: God Dog
items.excerpt: “You’re not going to like this, but this bitch is gonna blow, ” said the man, looking downward.

items.title: Suddenly Weightless
items.excerpt: The poet Alice Notley died on May 17. But death was a place that she had visited before, a state with which she had long communed.
